Fabrication of tannic acid promoted lignin-MOF hybrids derived catalysts for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Yin Wang Writing – original draft a Haihong Xia Software Data curation b Fei Ge Software a Yanrong Wang Writing – review & editing Validation a ⁎ Xiaohui Yang Validation Resources b ⁎ Jianchun Jiang Methodology Investigation b Minghao Zhou Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225002, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Yangzhou University Yangzhou 225002 China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou 225002, China b Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, Chinese Academy of Forestry, Nanjing 210042, China Institute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products Chinese Academy of Forestry Nanjing 210042 China bInstitute of Chemical Industry of Forest Products, Chinese Academy of Forestry, Nanjing 210042, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The catalytic conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) to value-added chemicals was quite vital for the conversion and utilization of biomass resources. The development of novel and efficient catalysts was of great significance. In this work, a series of tannic acid doped catalysts (Ni-Co/TA@C) were prepared by hydrothermal self-assembly method using lignosulfonate as a building block and coordinating with metal ions Ni2+ and Co2+. The effects of different preparation conditions and reaction conditions on the performance of the catalysts were investigated, and the optimal conditions for catalytic transfer hydrogenation were also explored. The results showed that the conversion of 5-HMF was 99.97% and the yield of 2,5-dimethyl furan (DMF) was as high as 87.10% with Ni2Co/TA@C as catalyst under mild reaction conditions (240 °C, 2 MPa N2, 4h). The surface morphology, surface area and composition of the catalysts were characterized in detail. The Ni2Co/TA@C catalyst had higher total acidity and larger amount of strong acid sites, which was conducive to highly selective catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of DMF, and the larger specific surface area also promoted the dispersion and loading of Ni and Co. This study provided some novel findings for the construction of catalysts for biomass conversion. Graphical abstract In this work, a series of tannic acid doped catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal self-assembly method using lignosulfonate as a building block and coordinating with metal ions Ni2+ and Co2+ for the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass 5-HMF DMF Tannic acid Catalytic transfer hydrogenation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Due to the overexploitation and consumption of non-renewable fossil resources, the environment has suffered serious damages. Thus, there is an urgent need to seek out renewable and green non-fossil resources [1–4]. Lignocellulosic biomass (cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin) has gained widespread attention in recent years due to its abundant reserves, easy accessibility, and wide application [5–7]. Among many biomass-derived platform compounds, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) is considered as a very crucial and versatile intermediate [8]. It can be further catalytically transformed into a wide range of high-value derivatives such as 5-methylfurfuryl alcohol (MFA) [9], 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) [10], 5-[(1-methylethoxy) methyl]-2-furanmethanol (MEFA) [11], 1,6-hexanediol [12], and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid[13] through hydrogenation, etherification, oxidation, decarboxylation, etc [14]. Among them, DMF, featuring an oxygen-containing rigid ring structure and a symmetrical dimethyl structure, is a kind of low-carbon bio-fuels that can serve as a substitute for conventional fuels like gasoline and diesel [15–17]. This is attributed to its high-octane number (RON = 119), greater energy density (30 kJ cm−3), suitable boiling point (93 °C), excellent miscibility with gasoline, and low moisture absorption [18–20]. Furthermore, DMF can serve as a substrate for the cycloaddition of olefins, leading to the production of aromatic compounds such as p-xylene via the Diels-Alder reaction. The significant potential of DMF in the field of sustainable energy solutions, combined with the challenges of achieving highly selective conversion of 5-HMF into DMF, has garnered increasing attention. In view of its importance, the production of DMF has been reported in many literatures. Yang et al. reported a catalytic transfer hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis process for converting 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) into the valuable chemical 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF). This reaction was carried out using a carbon supported nickel-cobalt catalyst with formic acid as hydrogen donor. The highest yield of DMF, 90.0%, was obtained at 210 °C under self-generated pressure. However, the reaction time was excessively long [24]. Shao et al. reported an alloying method for the selective conversion of 5-HMF to DMF, achieving a yield of 93.4% by incorporating Fe species into Ni–Al catalysts to form an oxyphilic FeNi alloy. The results indicated that the alloy formation in Ni–Fe–Al reduced the capability for hydrogen adsorption and activation, leading to decreased activity for hydrogenating the furan ring in 5-HMF. Additionally, the oxyphilic FeNi alloy demonstrated a high affinity for the adsorption/ activation of C–OH groups in BHMF and 5-MFA, which improved their hydrogenolysis to DMF. However, the initial hydrogen pressure for the reaction was notably high at 4 MPa, indicating that further optimization was needed [23]. Other 5-HMF catalytic hydrogenation works were shown in Table 1 . It was worth noting that most of the reactions were accompanied by a high hydrogen pressure and longer reaction time at similar reaction temperature, which suggested the superiority of our catalytic system. In recent years, significant advancements have been made in the development of precious metal catalysts, including Au/Al2O3 [30], PdxAuy/C [31], and Ru-Sn/ZnO [32], for selectively hydrogenating 5-HMF using H2 as a hydrogen source. Although those catalysts have shown promising catalytic results, the cost of precious metal catalysts and the use of H2, which is both flammable and explosive at high pressure, have prompted researchers to explore alternative methods [33]. Therefore, novel catalytic systems have been under investigation to tackle cost reduction. Those systems usually employ a disproportionation reaction [34], electrocatalytic method [35], or biocatalytic method [36] for the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF. Importantly, non-precious metal catalysts and the absence of external H2 are used in those systems. However, it is worth noting that these alternative methods have drawbacks such as lower catalytic selectivity and longer reaction times. Hence, there is an urgent need for an economical and effective catalytic system that can selectively hydrogenate 5-HMF into DMF. In summary, hydrogen donor such as isopropanol can be used as hydrogen source [37–39], and non-noble metal-based catalysts can be used to achieve the selective hydrogenation of 5-HMF. Nickel-based catalysts have been identified as potential candidates for the selective conversion of 5-HMF [40]. Due to the tunability of electronic and geometric structure, bimetallic nanoparticles have been proved to have superior catalytic activity to their monometallic parent materials [41,42]. Cobalt is an abundant metal with high availability and low price, and cobalt-based catalysts are widely used in hydrogenation reactions [43]. Moreover, cobalt-based catalyst is an excellent catalyst for biomass transfer hydrogenation with isopropanol as hydrogen source and solvent [44]. Therefore, attempts are made to introduce metallic cobalt into nickel-based catalysts [45,46]. Tannic acid (TA) is a natural, renewable, and environmentally friendly functional molecule with abundant carbon content and functional groups like gallic alcohol or catechol groups, which can be extracted from plant tissue [47]. These characteristics have led to a wide range of applications for TA. For instance, it is used in catalyst preparation [48,49]. The phenolic hydroxyl groups in tannic acid exhibit a strong chelating effect with metal ions, allowing them to act as ligands that coordinate with metal ions to form coordination catalysts [50]. Numerous studies have shown that tannic acid can coordinate with metal ions such as Zr, Hf, Ni, Cr, Cu, etc., for furfural hydrogenation and photoelectric catalysis [44,51,52]. In this work, nickel-cobalt bimetallic-lignin sulfonic acid hybrids NinCo-MOF-LS (n represents different metal ratios) were prepared by hydrothermal method as catalyst precursors. Carbon-supported nickel-cobalt tannic acid catalysts were successfully prepared by secondary hydrothermal introduction of tannic acid. After calcination, catalysts Ni-Co/TA@C were used for catalytic transfer hydrogenation of 5-HMF to DMF. Under mild reaction conditions (240 °C, 2 MPa N2, 4 h), Ni2Co/TA@C exhibited excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for 5-HMF hydrogenation to DMF. The effects of cobalt doping dosage, calcination temperature, tannic acid dosage, reaction conditions (temperature, time, catalyst dosage, N2 pressure) on selective hydrogenation were studied. This work could provide some references for the development of efficient biomass catalytic conversion catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF, 99%) and sodium lignosulfonate (LS) were provided by Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd. N, N-dimethylformamide (AR,≥99.5%), Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2 .6H2O), Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2 .6H2O), trimesic acid (99%+) and tannic acid (99%) were provided by Shanghai Titan Technology Co., Ltd. Ethanol (AR, ≥99.7%) and isopropanol (AR, ≥99.5%) were supplied by Shanghai Mylin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Nitrogen (99.999%) was purchased from Nanjing Lian Yang Gas Co., Ltd. All chemicals were utilized as received without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation On the basis of previous studies, the method was improved to prepare the catalyst [53]. The total dosage of metal doping was fixed at 10 mmol. Taking Ni2Co/TA@C with Ni:Co molar ratio of 2:1 as an example, the process of preparing the catalyst is as follows. Ni2Co-MOF-LS precursor was prepared by hydrothermal method. Ni(NO₃)₂·6H₂O (0.667 mmol), Co(NO₃)₂·6H₂O (0.333 mmol), sodium lignosulfonate (0.5 g) and trimesic acid (BTC) (10 mmol) were dissolved in 60 mL organic solvent N, N-dimethylformamide. Magnetons were added and stirred until the solid was completely dissolved. The mixed solution was transferred to a hydrothermal kettle and reacted at 150 °C for 12 h. After the reaction, the mixture was naturally cooled to room temperature, and the mixture in the hydrothermal kettle was filtered. The obtained solid product was repeatedly washed with ethanol to obtain a wet solid sample. The solid sample was placed in an oven and dried at 70 °C until the sample weight was constant to obtain the precursor Ni2Co-MOF-LS. Weighed 1 g grinding sieved precursor and 0.05 g tannic acid, added 40 mL ethanol, and then added magnetons to stir. After that, the steps of secondary hydrothermal, suction filtration, washing and drying were the same as those of precursor treatment. Under nitrogen atmosphere, the product obtained by secondary hydrothermal was placed in a tube furnace, calcined at 400 °C for 2 h, and the heating rate was 5 °C/min to obtain Ni2Co/TA@C catalyst. Catalysts Ni-Co/TA@C-X (X represent the following different compositions) with different metal ratios (single metal nickel, Ni:Co=4:1, 3:1, 2:1, 1:1), different ligands (trimesic acid, terephthalic acid, 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid, 2-Aminoterephthalic Acid), different lignin types (LS, AL, EL, KL), different tannic acid dosage (0.02 g, 0.05 g, 0.07 g), different lignosulfonate dosage (0.25 g, 0.50 g, 0.75 g, 1.00 g) and different calcination temperatures(300 °C, 400 °C, 500 °C) were prepared by the same method. 2.3 Hydrogenation of 5-HMF This experiment was conducted in a 50 mL stainless steel high-pressure reactor fed with 5-HMF (0.25 g), catalyst (0.05 g) and isopropanol (15 mL) as both solvent and hydrogen source. After purging with N2 three times to remove the air inside, the reactor maintained the required pressure for the reaction and then heated to a certain temperature. After reaction, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature. The quantitative analysis of liquid products was performed using a GC9790Plus gas chromatograph (Fuli GC9720 plus, FULI INSTRUMENTS) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and an RB-5 capillary column (30 m * 0.32 mm * 0.5 μm). The analysis conditions were set as follows: injector temperature at 250 °C, detector temperature at 270 °C; initial temperature set at 80 °C with a 2-minute hold; temperature ramping at 20 °C/min, reaching 280 °C over a 10-minute period, followed by a 2-minute hold. Samples were filtered through a 10 µm syringe filter, and n-dodecane served as an internal standard for calibration. The catalytic results were determined by quantifying the response area of the GC-FID peaks. Conversion of 5-HMF and product selectivity were calculated according to the total molarity definition. (1) 5 − HMF conversion ( % ) = ( 1 − moles of 5 − HMF in products starting moles of 5 − HMF ) × 100 (2) DMF yield ( % ) = moles of DMF in products starting moles of 5 − HMF × 100 2.4 Catalyst and products characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were performed using a Bruker D8 Advance instrument in Germany, with a scan speed of 5 °C/min and a scan range from 10° to 80°. Raman spectroscopy characterization was performed employing a Renishaw InVia Raman spectrometer with a 532 nm laser. The samples' morphology was characterized through scanning electron microscopy (SEM) using a TESCAN-VEGA3 instrument. Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was identified by Micrometrics AutoChem II chemisorption analyzer, where a (2920_0020) 5% NH3-He-30sccm was used to calibrate at a flow rate of 1.340 mmol/min. The content of metal in the catalysts was analyzed by an Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES: Aglient 5110). The BET structural properties of the catalysts were determined by N2 physisorption assay (micromertics Gemini VII 2990 analyzer). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained with a Thermo VG ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with the measured acquisition time (s): 60 times, dwell time (ms): 260. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction patterns of catalysts synthesized under different conditions were shown in Fig. 1 . It could be seen from Fig. 1 (a) that for the single metal nickel-based catalyst Ni/TA@C, three distinct characteristic diffraction peaks were observed at 2θ=44.5 °, 51.8 ° and 76.4 °, corresponding to Ni (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes (PDF # 04–0850) [54]. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=39.5 °, 41.9 °, 44.9 °, 58.6 °, 71.2 °, 78.2 °, 84.9 °, 86.2 ° and 88.1 ° were corresponded to Ni3C (110), (006), (113), (116), (300), (119), (220), (306) and (223) crystal planes (PDF # 06–0697), respectively. Additionally, the HR-TEM image revealed the presence of Ni3C NPs, displaying lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.202 nm (framed by white in Fig. 4, i1), which was corresponding to the (113) crystal plane of hexagonal Ni3C. The results indicated the existence of both Ni and Ni3C phase in catalyst Ni/TA@C. After the second non-precious metal Co was introduced into the Ni/TA@C catalyst to form NinCo/TA@C (n=1,2,3; representing different metal ratios) bimetallic catalysts, the XRD spectra of the catalyst NinCo/TA@C underwent significant changes. It could be seen that the characteristic diffraction peaks corresponding to Ni3C phase were weakened, which was probably owing to the reduction of Ni3C into metallic nickel. The characteristic peaks at 2θ=44.5 °, 51.8 ° and 76.4 ° could be observed, which were corresponded to the diffraction of (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes (PDF # 04–0850) of nickel. This phenomenon indicated that the addition of metal Co would lead to the decrease of the Ni3C phase, changing the morphology of the metal nickel. Further investigation revealed that in the XRD spectrum of the catalyst Ni3Co/TA@C obtained by adding metal Co in accordance with the ratio of Ni:Co=3:1, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=44.5 °, 51.8 ° and 76.4 ° were still clearly visible, but they became much weaker. After increasing the proportion of metal Co and adjusting the ratio of Ni:Co to 2:1, the XRD pattern became smooth obviously. In contrast, the characteristic peaks at 2θ=51.8 ° and 76.4 ° were almost disappeared, and only a weak and wide characteristic peak at 2θ=44.5 ° could be observed. The decreased intensity of nickel species confirmed that the catalyst Ni2Co/TA@C had better dispersion and smaller particles, which were more conducive to the performance of the catalyst. After increasing the metal Co again and adjusting the ratio of Ni:Co to 1:1, the three metal characteristic peaks became sharper instead. It could be seen that the excellent crystal structure was also formed on the basis of the appropriate Ni:Co metal ratio. By analyzing the XRD results, not only the existence of Ni and Ni3C phase in the catalyst was determined, but also it was confirmed that the addition of metal Co changed the crystal properties of the catalyst and the existence form of metal Ni. However, no obvious diffraction peaks associated with Co species were observed in the XRD pattern. According to the results of ICP, it was reasonable to speculate that the phenomenon was caused by the fact that the particle size of Co was too small to satisfy the condition of Braggs’ Law, preventing the detection of the corresponding diffraction peak. The XRD spectrum for catalysts obtained at different calcination temperatures were presented in Fig. 1 (b). It could be seen that there was no obvious diffraction peak at 300 °C because the temperature was too low, and the oxides Ni and Co in the catalyst were not reduced by carbon, so no obvious diffraction peak was formed. The temperatures of 400 °C and 500 °C could make the oxides Ni and Co in the catalyst reduced by carbon, and the XRD spectra at the two temperatures were similar. However, when the calcination temperature was higher (500 °C), the diffraction peak of metal Ni at 2θ=44.5 ° was obviously higher and sharper, and the diffraction peaks at 2θ=51.8 ° and 76.4 ° could be observed in the XRD spectrum under this calcination temperature. It could be seen that the dispersion at 500 °C was average, which was not conducive to the performance of the catalyst. In Fig. 1 (c), the dosage of tannic acid increased from 0.02 g, 0.05 g to 0.07 g, and the XRD spectra of the catalysts were generally similar. When the dosage of tannic acid increased from 0.02 g to 0.05 g, the characteristic peak at 2θ=44.5 ° became weaker and the peak shape became wider. After increasing from 0.05 g to 0.07 g, the characteristic peak at 2θ=44.5 ° almost did not change, but more obvious impurity peaks appeared in the range of 20 °- 40 °. The diffraction characteristic peaks of 2θ=51.8 ° and 76.4 ° could be slightly observed when the dosage of tannic acid is 0.02 g, but when the dosage of tannic acid increased, the diffraction characteristic peaks of 2θ=51.8 ° and 76.4 ° could not be reflected in the spectrum. The results indicated that the change of tannic acid dosage would also change the morphology and crystallization properties of metal Ni to a certain extent, but the influence was not very obvious. Similarly, it was shown in Fig. 1 (d) with the increase of the dosage LS from 0.25 g to 0.75 g, the diffraction peak of metal Ni at 2θ=44.5 ° first became flatter and smaller, and then became higher and sharper. The XRD patterns of the catalysts at 0.25 g and 0.75 g were similar and the effect was not ideal, and both catalysts could observe relatively obvious diffraction peaks at 2θ=51.8 ° and 76.4 °. Upon closer examination of the figure, it could be observed that the sharpness of the metal Ni diffraction peak at 2θ=44.5 ° followed the order: Ni2Co/TA@C-0.75 g LS > Ni2Co/TA@C-0.25 g LS > Ni2Co/TA@C-0.50 g LS. This observation correlated quite well with the corresponding catalytic effects in the following section, indicating that under identical conditions, Ni2Co/TA@C-0.50 gLS performed better than Ni2Co/TA@C-0.25 gLS, which in turn performed better than Ni2Co/TA@C-0.75 gLS. Overall, the results suggested that the dosage of LS could affect the structure of the catalyst, with Ni2Co/TA@C-0.50 g LS exhibiting the most optimal performance under the given conditions. Fig. 1 (e) showed the XRD spectra of the catalysts containing different ligands. When BTC was used as the ligand, the characteristic peaks of the XRD spectrum suggested excellent performance. After replacing with other ligands, the spectrum of the catalyst changed significantly: when PTA (Terephthalic acid) was used as the ligand, sharp characteristic peaks appeared at 2θ=44.5 °, 51.8 ° and 76.4 °, especially at 2θ=44.5 °. By replacing the ligand with DHTA (2, 5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid), it could be seen that although the characteristic peak at 2θ=44.5 ° was relatively flat, there were many sharp peaks between 5 ° and 40 °, which was not conducive to the catalytic process. From the conversion rate and selectivity results of the catalyst (Table 4), it could be concluded that the catalyst effect of adding lignin would be better than that of lignin-free catalyst, so it was necessary to consider the effect of the addition of specific of lignin types. It could be seen from Fig. 1 (f) that the diffraction peaks of metal Ni with AL at 2θ=44.5 °, 51.8 ° and 76.4 ° were more obvious and sharper than those with LS, especially at 2θ=44.5 °. Therefore, LS was a more suitable lignin type. Raman spectra of different catalysts were presented in Fig. 2 , and the specific defects were also verified [55]. The ID/IG values calculated from Raman spectra were 0.85, 0.94, 0.82, and 0.96 for Ni/TA@C, Ni2Co/TA@C-300, Ni2Co/TA@C-400 and Ni2Co/TA@C-500, respectively. It could be seen that the appropriate calcination temperature (400 °C) was beneficial to reduce the degree of catalyst defects. When the dosage of tannic acid was 0.02 g, 0.05 g and 0.07 g, the ID/IG was 0.94, 0.82 and 0.87, respectively. Therefore, when the dosage of tannic acid was 0.05 g, the degree of catalyst defects could also be reduced to a certain extent. The morphology and microstructure of selected catalysts were tested and shown in Fig. 3 . It could be seen that most of the synthesized catalysts were spherical. Observing from the SEM images (Fig. 3 a1-a5) of the single metal catalyst Ni/TA@C and the corresponding element mapping diagram, it could be seen that there were many pores on the surface of the three-dimensional spherical catalyst after calcination. And a large number of metal loading sites were located in the pores, it was confirmed in the further experimental sections that the chance of reacting with 5-HMF would be reduced, which was not conducive to the conversion of 5-HMF. Moreover, the element mapping diagram reflected that the distribution of metal Ni was not uniform, and the color of metal Ni on the left side of Fig. 3 (a3) was deepened. This was because of the sintering accumulation phenomenon, so the catalytic performance of Ni/TA@C was not very ideal. After the addition of metal Co, the pores on the surface of the catalyst disappeared and replaced by a large number of intricate columnar protrusions. Compared with the pores in Ni/TA@C, the columnar protrusions provided more external metal loading sites for the reaction, which would improve the catalytic performance in the further study. Compared with Fig. 3 (a3) and Fig. 3 (c3), it could also be seen that under the same conditions, the presence of Co specie could lead to the better dispersion of metal particles, and the particles also became more delicate, reflecting the smaller particle size of the metal particles. These findings undeniably confirmed the successful incorporation of Co specie and the introduction of Co could enhance the dispersion of metal nanoparticles. By comparing (b), (c), (d) in Fig. 3, the morphologies of the catalyst obtained at different calcination temperatures (corresponding to 300 °C, 400 °C and 500 °C, respectively) were observed. The catalyst structures were roughly similar, and the metal Ni and Co were evenly distributed on the catalyst. As the calcination temperature increased, the volume of the spherical catalyst in the figure gradually became smaller. The collapse of the catalyst skeleton at higher temperatures might lead to the decrease in volume. In addition, the calcination temperature had a significant effect on the surface morphology of the catalyst. When the calcination temperature was 300 °C, the columnar protrusions on the catalyst surface were small and accumulational, which was found not conducive to the adhesion of active metals. When the temperature was raised to 400 °C, the volume of columnar protrusions on the surface of the catalyst became larger and also resulted in a better dispersion. When the catalyst was heated to 500 °C again, the volume of columnar protrusions on the surface of the catalyst became smaller and agglomerated, which might due to the damage of the morphology under higher calcination temperature. Similarly, when changing the dosage of tannic acid, the overall morphology of the catalyst did not change greatly, but when the dosage was too low (0.02 g) or too high (0.07 g), the number of columnar protrusions on the surface of the catalyst was large but the volume was small, and there was a small dosage of agglomeration. The morphologies of the catalysts were not as good as that of the catalyst when the dosage was 0.05 g. The SEM images of Ni2Co/TA@C-BTC, Ni2Co/TA@C-PTA and Ni2Co/TA@C-DHTA was presented in Fig. 3 (c), (g) and (h), by studying the effect of different ligand. The ligand changed from BTC to PTA, and the catalyst particles became smaller, but still retained the spherical morphology. Amplified to 1.0 μm, a smooth surface was observed without columnar protrusions, and a large number of metal particles of different sizes were attached. Changing the ligand to DHTA, the catalyst no longer maintained a spherical shape, and the catalyst heavily agglomerated, forming clusters. At 1.0μm, a smooth surface of the catalyst and a large number of fine metal particles were also observed. TEM was conducted to observe surface and textural characteristics. It could be clearly seen from Fig. 4 that the average nanoparticles size of varied greatly, while the average size of Ni/TA@C, Ni2Co/TA@C-300, Ni2Co/TA@C-400, Ni2Co/TA@C-500, Ni2Co/TA@C-0.02 g TA, Ni2Co/TA@C-0.07 g TA, Ni2Co/TA@C-PTA and Ni2Co/TA@C-DHTA corresponded to about 23.5 nm, 3.7 nm, 20.1 nm, 8.0 nm, 23.7 nm, 6.6 nm, 18.9 nm and 13.7 nm, respectively. It might safely conclude that the introduction of Co specie could decrease the particle size to a different extent, which was in good accordance with the previous XRD analysis. Furthermore, by observing Fig. 4 (c), it was found that the particle size of the catalyst Ni2Co/TA@C-400 followed a standard normal distribution, indicating uniformity in the size of particle. Fig. 4 (i) showed the HR-TEM images of the catalyst Ni2Co/TA@C-400. The stripe spacing of Ni (0.203 nm), Ni3C (0.202 nm) and Co (0.204 nm) corresponded to the Ni (111), Ni3C (113) and Co (111) crystal planes, respectively. In addition, the HR-TEM images revealed the uniform distribution of Ni, Ni3C and Co elements in metal nanoparticles. To assess the acid properties of the catalysts, NH3-TPD methods was employed in this work [56]. A greater quantity of NH3 desorbed and a longer desorption time indicated higher concentrations of acidic species within the sample [14]. The peaks at 300 °C-600 °C and above 600 °C could be attributed to the NH3 desorption peaks of medium and strong acidic sites of the catalyst, respectively. It was presented in Fig. 5 and Table 2 that, all catalysts had an apparent NH3 desorption peak between 300 °C and 600 °C, which proved the existence of medium acidic sites on the catalyst surface. The Ni/TA@C catalyst was dominated by medium acid acidic sites, and the NH3 desorption peak of its strong acidic sites was very weak. With the increasing of Co specie, the area of the desorption peak of strong acid acidic sites increased significantly, which indicated that the introduction of Co specie was beneficial to increase the strong acid acidic sites of the catalyst. Furthermore, the catalyst's acidity was also influenced by the calcination temperature. Fig. 5 illustrated that with a rise in calcination temperature, the percentage of NH3 desorption peak area from the catalyst's strong acid sites gradually increased. However, from the perspective of total acidity, the increase of calcination temperature was not obviously conducive to the acidity of the catalyst. At a calcination temperature of 300 °C, the total acidity measured 4.36 mmol/g. Conversely, at 500 °C, the total acidity decreased to 2.38 mmol/g, leading to a significant reduction in the catalyst's acidity. This could be attributed to the rise in calcination temperature, which altered the support structure and damaged the acidic sites within the catalyst. Increasing or decreasing the dosage of tannic acid had no significant effect on the total acidity of the catalyst, but the NH3 desorption peak area of the strong acid site of the catalyst were both as high as 80%. After the ligand was replaced with PTA and DHTA, the total acidity value increased significantly, and the NH3 desorption peaks of the catalyst at the medium acid sites and the strong acid sites were significant. The catalyst's high activity might be attributed to its plentiful strongly acidic sites. It has been noted that a stronger acid strength could enhance hydrogen transfer and inhibit side reactions [57]. As shown in the Fig. 6 (a), XPS spectra confirmed the presence of Ni, Co, O and C elements on the catalysts at different calcination temperatures. The XPS spectra of Co 2p of these catalysts included three components: Co0, Co2+ and satellite peaks [58], whereas the XPS spectra of Ni 2p also included three components: Ni0, Ni2+ and satellite peaks [59,60]. Fig. 6 (d) and (e) showed the Ni 2p and Co 2p spectra of Ni2Co/TA@C-400 calcined at 400 °C. The peaks for Ni0 2p1/2 and Ni0 2p3/2 appeared at 852.9 eV and 870.0 eV, and the ones for Ni2+ 2p1/2 and Ni2+ 2p3/2 were located at 854.8 eV and 872.1 eV. Besides, there were two satellite peaks of Ni at 859.0 eV and 874.9 eV. All the XPS spectra exhibited peaks corresponding to Ni3C and Ni. The peaks at 778.4 eV and 793.5 eV were corresponded to metallic Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2, respectively. The peaks corresponding to Co2+ 2p3/2 and Co2+ 2p1/2 were detected at 781.6 eV and 797.4 eV, which were identified as Co2+ peaks for CoO [58]. The two peaks at 780.6 eV and 796.6 eV had strong satellite peaks. The existence of Co2+ specie suggested that the Co ions in the catalyst had not undergone complete reduction, a factor that could be advantageous for the formation of acidic sites. The chemical compositions of the catalysts calcined at different temperatures were determined by ICP method. No obvious diffraction peak of Co was observed in XRD, but the presence of metal Co could be clearly seen in ICP results. It could be inferred that Co nanoparticles were too small to detect and had a high degree of dispersion. The calcination temperature had a significant effect on the chemical composition of the catalyst. As the temperature increased, the metal loading of Ni and Co gradually increased obviously, mainly because the specific surface area of the catalyst increased with temperature (visible from BET characterization results). At 300 °C, the surface of the catalyst was slightly rough. After heating to 400 °C, the surface became rougher and better columnar protrusions appeared. After heating to 500 °C, the surface of the catalyst became smoother (see SEM characterization). The two factors of metal loading and surface roughness determined that the catalyst calcined at 400 °C had the best catalytic performance. The metal Ni and Co were mainly supported on the columnar protrusions on the surface of the catalyst, which could provide more catalytic sites for the reaction. The catalysts' surface properties were assessed through N2 adsorption-desorption characteristics, encompassing specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for some catalysts are depicted in Fig. 7 . The pore size of all catalysts was less than 50 nm, showing mesoporous structure. The pore size distribution of Ni/TA@C was obviously observed in the range of 2–15 nm, and the pore size of other catalysts was basically less than 5 nm. In particular, Ni2Co/TA@C-400 might also have some microporous structure. In Table 4, the specific surface area at 300 °C was very small, only 14.61 m2/g, and the pore volume was only 0.05 cm3/g. It could be seen that calcination at 300 °C was not conducive to the formation of the pore structure of the catalyst, so the catalyst Ni2Co/TA@C-300 had a common effect and was not conducive to the reaction. With the increase of calcination temperature, the specific surface area and pore volume increased significantly, and the pore size decreased. It could be seen that the higher calcination temperature was more conducive to the formation of the catalyst structure. The specific surface area of the single metal catalyst Ni/TA@C was 58.74 m2/g, the pore volume was 0.17 cm3/g, and the pore size was 7.51 nm. In contrast, it could be seen that the addition of metal Co made the structure of the catalyst obviously optimized, which further proved the rationality of the introduction of metal Co. The appropriate dosage of tannic acid could obtain a better catalyst structure. It could be seen from Table 3 that when 0.05 g tannic acid was added, the catalyst structure was optimal and the catalytic effect was the best. On this basis, increasing or decreasing the dosage of tannic acid was not conducive to the performance of the catalyst. 3.2 Selection of the catalyst The catalytic performances of different catalysts under certain conditions were summarized in Table 5 . In the control experiment, the activity of single metal catalyst was first investigated, while the conversion rate was high, but the selectivity was poor, with a large number of by-products. The SEM characterization revealed that there were many pores on the surface of the catalyst. Within these pores, a significant number of metal loading sites were distributed which were not favorable for the conversion of 5-HMF. In order to improve the yield of DMF in 5-HMF hydrogenation reaction, the catalysts with different Ni/Co molar ratios were systematically studied. After adding a small dosage of metal Co in the ratio of Ni:Co=4:1, the selectivity of the target product DMF was improved to some extent, indicating that the introduction of metal Co improved the selectivity of the catalyst. Increasing the dosage of Co and adjusting the metal ratio to 3:1, the yield of DMF was still increasing, but the selectivity was still not very ideal. Continuing to adjust the metal ratio to 2:1, from Table 5, the yield of DMF was as high as 87.10%, and the yield of other products also decreased, the performance of the catalyst was better. Continuing to increase the dosage of metal Co to improve catalyst performance, but the catalytic results were extremely poor, with incomplete hydrogenation and a decrease in conversion rate from 99.98% to 64.05%. Not only that, the selectivity for DMF was also the worst, which was worse than the catalytic effect of single metal Ni. In summary, the choice of 2:1 was the best metal ratio. It could be seen that the addition of metal Co was beneficial to the performance of the catalyst to a certain extent, but excessive Co content would also lead to worse catalytic performance, because the two active metals had a synergistic effect. The results from SEM characterization indicated that the incorporation of metal cobalt was highly favorable for the reaction. Combined with the characterization results of NH3-TPD, it was observed that the presence of cobalt enhanced the number of strong acid sites on the catalyst, which were used to assist the polarization and activation of C-OH bonds in BHMF and MFA, thereby generating the target product DMF. Therefore, finding the appropriate bimetallic ratio laid a solid foundation for the process of exploring the optimal catalyst. Under the optimal metal ratio, the catalyst was further optimized. The calcination temperature increased from 300 to 500 °C, and the effect of the catalyst showed a huge gap. In Table 5, when the calcination temperature was 300 °C, the conversion of 5-HMF was only 21.79%, the remaining 78.21% of 5-HMF was not involved in the reaction, and the yield of DMF was less than 1%. When the temperature was raised to 400 °C, the catalyst performance was excellent. Raman characterization results also showed that the defect degree of the catalyst was the lowest when calcined at 400 °C. When the temperature was further increased to 500 °C, although the conversion of 5-HMF was still as high as 99.83%, the yield of the target product DMF plummeted to 53.11%, and more by-products appeared. This phenomenon could be explained by SEM analysis. An excessive calcination temperature could cause the catalyst's framework to collapse, subsequently reducing its volume that was detrimental to the catalytic activity. NH3-TPD results also showed that intense heat during calcination could lead to the destruction of the catalyst's strong acidic sites. From Table 5, it was observed that the lignin doped in the catalyst was also worthy of attention. The conversion of 5-HMF was as high as 99.61% and the yield of DMF was 73.34% when lignin was not added to the catalyst. The catalytic performance was better than that of most other prepared catalysts. After the addition of LS, the by-products of 5-HMF hydrogenation to DMF were reduced, and the yield reached 87.10%. The catalytic performance was much better. However, the conversion of 5-HMF and the yield of DMF were greatly reduced after replacing the lignin species with AL (Alkali lignin), EL (Enzymatic lignin) and KL (Kraft lignin), which was much worse than that of the catalyst without lignin. It could be seen that the type of lignin had a significant effect on the catalyst performance. On this basis, changing the dosage of LS, it could be found that there was almost no effect on the conversion of 5-HMF, and the yield of DMF was also higher than 70%. When the dosage of LS was 0.5 g, the catalytic effect was the best. On the other hand, with the increasing of the TA dosage from 0.02 g to 0.07 g corresponding to the yield of DMF from 40.30% to 87.10%, which was increased significantly. Further increasing the TA dosage, the yield of DMF decreased decidedly to 69.44% under excessive TA dosage. This phenomenon could be explained by SEM analysis, and a small amount of agglomeration would lead to poor performance of the catalyst. However, changing the dosage of TA had no significant effect on the conversion rate of 5-HMF, which were higher than 95% (nearly total conversion). 3.3 Optimization of the reaction conditions over Ni2Co/TA@C-400 catalyst The effects of different reaction conditions, including reaction temperature, N2 pressure, time and catalyst dosage on the hydrogenation of 5-HMF over Ni2Co/TA@C-400 catalyst were investigated. It could be seen from Fig. 8 that the yield of DMF was 87.10% under the optimum conditions (240 °C, 2 MPa N2, 4 h and 50 mg catalyst). Fig. 8 (a) showed the activities data of the reaction with different reaction temperature. At 180 °C, the conversion of 5-HMF was only 18.02%, and the yield of DMF was only 1.24%. When the temperature was increased to 200 °C, the conversion rate was significantly increased to 50.35%, but the yield to DMF was still less than 10%. It could be seen that increasing the temperature on this basis was beneficial to the performance of the catalyst. When the temperature was raised to 220 °C, the conversion rate was as high as 99.63%, and the yield of DMF also increased to 60.32%, but it still did not meet the expectations. When the temperature rised to 240 °C, the conversion of 5-HMF still increased slightly to 99.98%, which was close to complete conversion. The yield of DMF was as high as 87.10%, and the catalyst effect was ideal. However, with the further increase of reaction temperature, the yield of DMF decreased because of the excess formation of by-products. Therefore, 240 °C was selected as the optimum reaction temperature. When the N2 pressure was 0 MPa, 5-HMF was not completely converted, and the main product of the reaction were BHMF and 5-MF. After pressurizing to 1 MPa, the conversion of 5-HMF reached 99.83%, but the DMF yield of 75.47% was not excellent. However, it could be seen that the introduction of N2 was beneficial to the catalytic process. Therefore, the pressure of N2 was increased to evaluate the catalytic results. The conversion of 5-HMF reached 99.98% and the yield of DMF reached 87.10% under 2 MPa N2 atmosphere. However, when the pressure increased to 3 MPa, although a similar 5-HMF conversion rate (99.88%) was obtained, the yield of DMF decreased to 74.36%. It could be seen that the N2 pressure of 2 MPa was sufficient to convert 5-HMF, and the catalytic performance was also good. As the reaction time increased from 1 h to 3 h, the conversion rate slowly increased from 32.03% to 50.77%, but the yield of DMF was almost unchanged, which was always lower than 5%. When the reaction time continued to increase to 4 h, the conversion rate increased sharply to 99.98%, and the yield of DMF also increased significantly to 87.10%. With the further extension of the reaction time, the conversion rate of 5-HMF was in a stable stage, and the yield of DMF plummeted to 66.25%. The sharp decrease in the yield of DMF might be due to its hydrodeoxygenation to by-products in a longer time. Therefore, 4 h was the best reaction time. The dosage of catalyst also affected the catalytic activity to a certain extent. From Fig. 8 (d), it was evident that the conversion rate of 5-HMF was excellent (higher than 99%). It also could be seen that the dosage of catalyst had little effect on the conversion rate of 5-HMF, which could be ignored, but the effect on the yield of DMF needed to be considered. When the dosage of catalyst was 25 mg and 40 mg, the yield of DMF increased slightly with the increase of catalyst weight, but both were less than 75%. The yield of DMF was 87.10% when the dosage was further increased to 50 mg. When the dosage of catalyst was increased to 60 mg, the yield of DMF decreased to 70.95%. It could be seen that excessive catalyst was not conducive to catalysis. When the dosage was 75 mg, the yield of DMF increased slightly to 73.23%, which was negligible. When the dosage was further increased to 100 mg, the yield of DMF was less than 70%, which proved that the dosage of catalyst should also be appropriately added. Therefore, 50 mg was selected as the optimal catalyst dosage. 3.4 Catalyst recyclability The reusability of the Ni2Co/TA@C-400 catalyst was tested for the transfer hydrogenolysis of 5-HMF. After the reaction, the catalyst was collected, washed and dried with isopropyl alcohol and used for the next run. After 6 reactions, the conversion rate of 5-HMF was still higher than 99.9%. After four consecutive runs, the DMF yield was reduced from 87% to 66%. In the following two reactions, although the yield was slightly increased, it was almost stable at 68%, indicating that Ni2Co/TA@C-400 had good repeatability and practicability, but there was still room for improvement (Fig. 9 ). 3.5 Reaction pathway study There were two main reaction paths for the conversion of 5-HMF to DMF (Fig. 10 ). The first reaction path was that the aldehyde group was hydrogenated into hydroxyl group to generate BHMF, and then the hydroxyl group was removed to form MFA. The second reaction pathway was that 5-HMF first removed the hydroxyl group to form 5-MF, and then the aldehyde group was hydrogenated to form MFA [61]. Finally, DMF was produced by further hydrogenolysis of MFA. In a reducing environment, the activation of the C=O bond was easier both kinetically and thermodynamically than that of the C-OH bond. This resulted in the C=O bond being more readily hydrogenated to form a C-OH bond, thereby leading to the formation of BHMF in general conditions. The reaction mechanism also could be inferred from the reaction time. When the reaction time was 1 h, the conversion rate of 5-HMF was only 32.03%, and the yield of BHMF was as high as 22.94%. The yield of BHMF was almost unchanged when the reaction time increased from 1 h to 3 h. Similarly, the yield of 5-MF could be found to increase slowly with time, probably because it was more difficult for 5-MF to convert into MFA. The rate of 5-HMF to 5-MF was greater than that of 5-MF to MFA, so 5-MF accumulated with time and the yield increased. In this process, most of the raw material 5-HMF did not participate in the reaction, the yield of MFA and the target product DMF also barely changed. It could be inferred that the first 3 h were mainly a slow process of accumulation of intermediate products. Moreover, 5-HMF was preferentially converted into BHMF, and then DMF was generated along the reaction path. The catalytic reaction mechanism was speculated after the reaction path was known. For the dehydrogenation reaction of isopropanol, the hydroxyl group of isopropanol might initially interact with the active sites on the catalyst surface. This interaction allowed for the extraction of the hydrogen atom from the alcoholic group, resulting in the formation of adsorbed alkoxide species. Subsequently, the β-hydrogen atom was further removed, leading to the production of acetone. Concurrently, the generated active hydrogen could further engage in the hydrogenolysis of 5-HMF. In the initial stage of the hydrogenolysis process, the carbonyl oxygen of 5-HMF, which possessed lone pairs of electrons, firstly adsorbed on electrophilic Ni2+ and Co2+ species. This interaction enhanced the activation of the C=O bond. Subsequently, the carbonyl group in 5-HMF was hydrogenated to BHMF under the catalysis of metal nanoparticles by using the abstracted hydrogen. Thereafter, the surface electrophilic Ni2+ and Co2+ species, functioning as Lewis acid sites, assisted in the polarization and activation of the C−O bond in BHMF and MFA. This process ultimately resulted in the production of DMF with the help of the Ni and Co metal nanoparticles. 4 Conclusion In summary, we fabricated a series of tannic acid-doped bimetallic catalysts Ni-Co/TA@C composites with spherical Ni-Co core and a porous structure derived from MOFs, and systematically investigated the effects of preparation process and reaction conditions on the catalyst. Compared with other catalysts, Ni2Co/TA@C-400 had excellent selectivity and activity for the hydrogenation of 5-HMF to DMF. Under the optimized reaction conditions (240 °C, 2 MPa N2, 4 h), the conversion of 5-HMF on Ni2Co/TA@C-400 was 99.97%, and the yield of DMF was 87.10%. This could be attributed to the highly dispersed active metal in the tannic acid doped metal organic framework. In addition, the synergistic effect of Ni and Co was also beneficial to the hydrogenation of 5-HMF to DMF. This study could provide a new reference for the construction of catalysts in the field of biomass conversion and open up a potential way for the high-value utilization of tannic acid resources. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (5-HMF) to value-added chemicals was quite vital for the conversion and utilization of biomass resources. The development of novel and efficient catalysts was of great significance. In this work, a series of tannic acid doped catalysts (Ni-Co/TA@C) were prepared by hydrothermal self-assembly method using lignosulfonate as a building block and coordinating with metal ions Ni2+ and Co2+. The effects of different preparation conditions and reaction conditions on the performance of the catalysts were investigated, and the optimal conditions for catalytic transfer hydrogenation were also explored. The results showed that the conversion of 5-HMF was 99.97% and the yield of 2,5-dimethyl furan (DMF) was as high as 87.10% with Ni2Co/TA@C as catalyst under mild reaction conditions (240 °C, 2 MPa N2, 4h). The surface morphology, surface area and composition of the catalysts were characterized in detail. The Ni2Co/TA@C catalyst had higher total acidity and larger amount of strong acid sites, which was conducive to highly selective catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of DMF, and the larger specific surface area also promoted the dispersion and loading of Ni and Co. This study provided some novel findings for the construction of catalysts for biomass conversion.
